title: 108_s2205
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that Ukraine allows its citizens the right to emigrate without excessive taxes or charges, has been compliant with freedom of emigration requirements since 1997, and has made progress towards democracy since 1991. Since 1997, Ukraine has complied with freedom of emigration requirements under the Trade Act of 1974. After regaining independence in 1991, Ukraine has made significant strides towards establishing democratic institutions and a free-market economy. As a member of the OSCE, Ukraine is dedicated to developing a governance system aligned with human rights principles outlined in the Helsinki Final Act. Ukraine has made progress in meeting international commitments and standards in its recent Parliamentary elections, despite significant shortcomings in the implementation of election laws and allegations of interference in the electoral process. Despite significant shortcomings in the implementation of election laws and allegations of interference, Ukraine is committed to addressing issues related to its national and religious minorities and ensuring equality for persons belonging to national minorities. Ukraine has enacted legislation providing protection. Ukraine has enacted legislation to protect against incitement to violence based on discrimination, including anti-Semitism, and is committed to ensuring freedom of religion and combating racial and ethnic intolerance and hatred. Ukraine is actively combating ethnic and religious intolerance by cooperating with US NGOs and restoring religious properties confiscated during the Soviet era. Ukraine is developing a legislative framework to return confiscated properties to national and religious minorities, aiding in their revival. The country has normal trade relations with the US and is progressing towards joining the World Trade Organization. Ukraine is making progress towards joining the World Trade Organization, with unresolved issues including access for US agricultural products, intellectual property rights, tariff reductions, trade in services, agricultural subsidies, export incentives, and customs reforms. Ukraine has enacted protections for labor rights and committed to respecting freedom of the press as an OSCE member. Positive relations have been established with other countries. Ukraine, as an OSCE member, has committed to respecting freedom of the press despite ongoing infringements. It has positive relations with neighboring countries and aims for European integration, prioritizing democracy and prosperity. Additionally, Ukraine has collaborated with the United States in peacekeeping operations in Europe and contributed to the global fight against terrorism. SEC. 2. TERMINATION OF APPLICATION OF TITLE IV OF THE TRADE ACT OF 1974 TO UKRAINE. The President may determine that title IV of the Trade Act of 1974 should no longer apply to Ukraine and proclaim the extension of permanent normal trade relations treatment to Ukrainian products. The Trade Act of 1974 may no longer apply to Ukraine, and permanent normal trade relations treatment will be extended to Ukrainian products, terminating the application of Title IV for that country. The Trade Act of 1974 may no longer apply to Ukraine, and permanent normal trade relations treatment will be extended to Ukrainian products, terminating the application of Title IV for that country. The Sense of Congress is stated in Section 3. The Congress emphasizes the importance of the United States' continued engagement with Ukraine, urging Ukraine to fulfill its commitments as an OSCE member, including promoting free emigration, safeguarding religious liberty, and combating discrimination and violence. The United States urges Ukraine to enforce laws against discrimination and violence, expand restitution of religious properties, and respect media freedoms. They also aim to work with Ukraine to improve in various areas. The United States supports Ukraine in enforcing laws against discrimination and violence, expanding restitution of religious properties, respecting media freedoms, improving in various areas, protecting intellectual property rights, resolving trade disputes quickly, and monitoring human rights. The United States supports Ukraine in enforcing laws against discrimination and violence, expanding restitution of religious properties, respecting media freedoms, protecting intellectual property rights, resolving trade disputes quickly, and monitoring human rights, rule of law, and media freedoms in Ukraine. The United States provides assistance to NGOs and human rights groups in Ukraine for activities related to human rights, democracy, and rule of law. They aim to establish annual discussions with Ukraine on these issues involving US and Ukrainian NGOs. SEC. 4. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. The reports required by sections 102(b) and 203 of the International Religious Freedom Act of 1998 shall include an assessment of the status of certain issues. SEC. 5. CONTINUED ENJOYMENT OF RIGHTS UNDER THE JUNE 23, 1992, BILATERAL TRADE AGREEMENT. The trade agreement between the US and Ukraine from June 23, 1992, remains in force, granting the US rights to use safeguard rules against import surges from Ukraine under Section 421 of the Trade Act of 1974. SEC. 6. EXERCISE OF CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT OVER WTO ACCESSION NEGOTIATIONS. The President must notify Congress within 5 days of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession. A report detailing the agreement must be transmitted to Congress within 15 days. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced in Congress within 30 days, it may impact the agreement. If a resolution of disapproval is introduced in Congress within 30 days of the President notifying Congress of the US-Ukraine bilateral agreement on WTO accession, it shall be considered according to specific procedures. Congress must consider a resolution of disapproval regarding the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession within 30 days of notification by the President. The sense of Congress is that the US-Ukraine agreement on WTO accession does not adequately advance US interests. Resolutions of disapproval can be introduced by any Member of the House. Resolutions of disapproval can be introduced by any Member of the House and are referred to the Committee on Ways and Means and the Committee on Rules. In the Senate, these resolutions may not be amended by either Committee. In the Senate, resolutions of disapproval may be introduced by any Member and referred to the Committee on Finance, where they may not be amended. The Committee on Finance handles resolutions of disapproval in the Senate, which cannot be amended. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate apply to the resolution of disapproval in the same way as other resolutions. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate apply to a resolution of disapproval in the same way as other resolutions, enacted by Congress as part of their rulemaking power. The rules of each House supersede other rules to the extent of inconsistency, with the constitutional right to change rules at any time.
